question: The rate of turn indicator uses (i) …………… which spins (ii)……………….

choices.choice: rate gyro up and away from the pilot
space gyroscope up and away from the pilot
earth gyro Clockwise
tied gyro anti-clockwise when viewed from above

explanation:
THAP-1

  • T: Turn and Slip Indicator
  • H: Horizontal [Lateral Axis] [Pitch Axis]
  • A: Axis
  • P: Precession
  • 1: 1 Degree of Freedom

Freedom of movement is in one plane only – Rolling Plane.

 

The gyroscope in a rate of turn indicator spins in one direction and points in the direction the ship or aircraft is turning. 

When the ship or aircraft is traveling in a straight line, the gyroscope points straight and the pointer on the display shows zero. When the ship or aircraft turns, the gyroscope turns in the same direction and the pointer indicates the rate of turn
subject: Instruments

question: If the filter of the air driven rate of turn indicator becomes partially blocked:

choices.choice: the instrument will overread
the aircraft will turn faster than indicated
the radius of the turn will decrease
the rate of turn indicated will be unaffected

explanation:
If the suction is inadequate (at high altitude, or with a choked filter, or a leaking suction tube)
with an air driven instrument, gyro rigidity will be lowered as the gyro is “underspeeding”.
Consequently the secondary precession needed to equal the aircraft turn can be generated by
a smaller secondary torque. This reduced torque will be produced by a smaller angle of gimbal
tilt, and this means that the instrument will under-read the turn rate or in otherwords aircraft is turning fatser tahn being shown in instruments.
subject: Instruments

question: The TBI shown alongside indicates:

choices.choice: that the aircraft will complete a turn in one minute
an aircraft taxiing and turning starboard
a rate of turn to the left, slipping in
the aircraft is yawing to the right

explanation:
When turning to the left, if the ball moves to the left, it indicates that the aircraft is slipping in the turn.

When turning to the left, if the ball moves to the right, it indicates that the aircraft is skidding out of the turn.

When turning to the left and the ball stays in the center, it indicates a well-coordinated turn.
subject: Instruments
